title: Truth About Fluoride
description: The top bottled water brands tested for fluoride.

body.raw: _This information was taken and rewritten from [Truth About Flouride](https://truthaboutfluoride.com/)_ Bottled water might seem like a pure and simple solution to your hydration needs, but it's worth taking a closer look. While it's often marketed as 'natural' and 'clean,' the reality is that the contents of each bottle can vary significantly depending on its source and the processes it's undergone. Some bottled waters contain added minerals for taste, while others might have trace amounts of contaminants, despite rigorous filtration processes. ## How To Choose The Best Bottled Water When it comes to choosing the best bottled water, there are 6 factors you should consider: 1. Fluoride Content: Look for water with low fluoride levels to keep this controversial chemical to a minimum. 2. Microplastic Levels: Demand clear information from companies about any microplastics in their water; your health deserves purity. 3. Container Material: Select bottles that are kind to your wellbeing and the environment, such as those without BPA and that are recyclable. 4. Minerals + Additives: Prefer water that naturally contains beneficial minerals and is free from unnecessary additives. 5. Other Toxins: Stay informed about any potential toxins that might be in the water you're drinking. 6. Source of Water: Make sure the water you choose comes from a clean and uncontaminated source. ## 1. Flouride Content When discussing fluoride, we aim for minimal levels due to associated health risks. Low fluoride concentrations also suggest that water has been effectively filtered, especially since it's a challenging substance to remove. Brands with low fluoride are likely implementing robust filtration methods. Conversely, brands offering unfiltered, natural water are generally expected to have minimal contamination, given that natural sources typically contain around 0.05 ppm of fluoride. ## 2. Micropalstic Levels Regarding microplastics, the consensus is clear: they have no place in our bodies and can cause various health issues. Even though there's limited research on microplastics in bottled water, available studies enable us to identify which brands are less likely to pose a risk. Always stay informed and select your water wisely, prioritizing both your health and the planet's well-being. ## 3. Container Material When considering the material of the container for your water—be it plastic or glass—it's essential to weigh the options. Glass is typically preferred over plastic, as it eliminates the concern of chemical leaching into the water, which can occur with plastic containers. Often, water housed in glass tends to be of superior quality and, consequently, a healthier choice. However, the cost factor is real; glass-bottled water can be a significant expense. In such cases, a reliable water filter, once tested and verified, can serve as an economical and effective substitute for bottled water. ## 4. Minerals & Additives Many brands simply filter their water and reintroduce minerals artificially. These synthetic minerals are typically of inferior quality when compared to those naturally present in water and food sources. Moreover, it's not just about minerals. Certain water brands might also add subpar salt, artificial flavors, or so-called "natural flavors," which could be detrimental to your health over time. So, what's the advisable course of action? Opt for water that contains naturally occurring minerals, without any added extras—this is the water humans have been drinking for millennia. It's the most beneficial for your well-being. If that's not feasible, the next viable option is filtering your water at home. ## 5. Additional contaminant concerns Even with fluoride content managed and other factors addressed, there could still be other contaminants lurking in bottled water. Take Perrier as an instance – it may seem like a wise choice with its low fluoride content (0.1 ppm), glass packaging, and natural spring water origin. However, recent findings have indicated elevated levels of PFAS in Perrier's sparkling water, which unfortunately disqualifies it. Similarly, Topo Chico might appear appealing, but it was found to have exceedingly high PFAS levels, raising concerns. ## 6. Water source A significant issue with bottled water is the diversity of sources from which brands procure their water. Consider Kirkland (Costco) - they market spring water that looks uniform globally. Yet, a bottle purchased in Florida, USA compared to one from LA, California will contain water from two distinct sources, leading to potential differences in quality. One may have no detectable fluoride, whereas the other could contain 0.3 ppm or more. Therefore, it's crucial to verify the water's source with the information provided below. This is also why I have a preference for brands that exclusively source their water from a single locale, ensuring consistency and peace of mind about the water's safety and quality. Now, keeping these and other factors in mind, I'm ready to introduce you to the brands that I firmly believe stand out as the best… ## The Best Brands Of Bottled Water Requirements: - Must be fluoride-free, with a 0.0 ppm fluoride content as per testing - Should contain very low levels of microplastics - Availability in both glass and plastic bottles is necessary - Originating from natural sources such as the French Alps is preferred Best brands of bottled water: - Evian - Mountain Valley - Icelandic Glacial - Eska - San Benedetto - Acqua Panna - Highland Spring - Aqua Carpatica ## Additional Options It is recommended to consider only two scenarios for drinking water, each with its own advantages and drawbacks. The optimal approach for ensuring 100% confidence in water quality is to use a water filtration system. The key advantage here is that you have full control over the filtration process. With a high-quality water filter, the chances of anything going awry are minimal. Alternatively, it is recommended to opt for bottled water from the brands listed above, which offer natural water, packaged in glass, and with low fluoride and other toxins. When it comes to other bottled water brands, the risks outweigh the benefits. The presence of microplastics, unnatural minerals, and additives, coupled with the uncertainty of the water's contents, makes them a less desirable choice. Not to mention, the cost is often higher than justified. ## More important information It is imperative to examine not only the fluoride content but also the provenance of the bottled water brand you choose. This refers to the original body of water from which the company sources its product, whether it's a lake, river, or underground aquifer. Understanding this ensures that even if two bottles appear identical, they may contain vastly different water. Confirming the source is a definitive step to guarantee that the water you're consuming has low fluoride levels. Here are some strategies to assist you: 1. The source information is often listed on the bottle's label. Absence of this detail typically implies the water has been filtered. Labels that indicate "Purified" or "Distilled" suggest the water is devoid of fluoride. 2. Look up the brand name for quicker access to information. On a computer, the shortcut Command + “F” can expedite your search. 3. If you're not using the search function, the brands are organized alphabetically and then numerically for your convenience. Simply navigate to the section that matches the first letter of the brand you are searching for. 4. The term “Filtered” on the label signifies the original water source is irrelevant due to the filtration process, which standardizes the fluoride content. 5. “Single Source” indicates that the company uses one consistent source, ensuring uniform fluoride levels regardless of the specific origin. 6. If the source is listed as “Unknown,” the brand has not disclosed this information, which may suggest variability in fluoride content and presents a higher risk. ## Bottled water Flouride levels | common questions **Do Water Filters Remove Essential Minerals?** It's a common misconception that water filters strip away all the beneficial minerals from water. Indeed, minerals are essential for our health, but the truth is, tap water isn't a significant source of these nutrients. The minerals that are present in tap water can be of questionable quality due to potential damage from harsh treatment chemicals. When filtering tap water, you're not missing out on much in terms of beneficial minerals. It's also worth noting that relying on water alone for your mineral intake isn't a wise strategy. The quantities are simply too low, and if minerals are added to water by a brand, they are often not of optimal quality. These synthetic additives can be treated differently by the body compared to natural minerals. For an effective solution, incorporate these essential nutrients into your diet. Alternatively, you can add a pinch of quality salt to your filtered water. High-quality sea salt, or my personal preference, Redmond Real Salt, are excellent choices. However, steer clear of regular white table salt, as it's typically stripped of its natural benefits. **What about water brands not featured on this list?** If you come across a water brand that isn't featured on our recommended list, don't worry. It can still be a viable option as long as it meets the following criteria: it's natural, low in fluoride, free from additives, and ideally packaged in glass. If you're uncertain about a brand, reach out with the name, and we can help determine its suitability. **Is flavored water ok?** When it comes to flavored water, there's a sea of options that might not be as healthy as they claim. Many brands use "natural flavors," a term that unfortunately often encompasses a variety of undisclosed chemicals. The recommendation here is straightforward: choose brands like Spindrift, which uses actual squeezed fruit in their beverages, ensuring an all-natural, fluoride-free refreshment.

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`Bottled water might seem like a pure and simple solution to your hydration needs, but
it's worth taking a closer look. While it's often marketed as 'natural' and 'clean,'
the reality is that the contents of each bottle can vary significantly depending on its
source and the processes it's undergone. Some bottled waters contain added minerals for taste,
while others might have trace amounts of contaminants, despite rigorous filtration processes.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:18,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.li,{children:"Container Material: Select bottles that are kind to your wellbeing and the environment, such as those without BPA and that are recyclable."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:30,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.li,{children:"Source of Water: Make sure the water you choose comes from a clean and uncontaminated source."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:33,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.h2,{children:"1. Flouride Content"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:35,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`When discussing fluoride, we aim for minimal levels due to associated health risks.
Low fluoride concentrations also suggest that water has been effectively filtered,
especially since it's a challenging substance to remove. Brands with low fluoride are
likely implementing robust filtration methods. Conversely, brands offering unfiltered, natural
water are generally expected to have minimal contamination, given that natural sources typically
contain around 0.05 ppm of fluoride.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:37,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.h2,{children:"2. Micropalstic Levels"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:44,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`Regarding microplastics, the consensus is clear: they have no place in our bodies
and can cause various health issues. Even though there's limited research on microplastics
in bottled water, available studies enable us to identify which brands are less likely to
pose a risk. Always stay informed and select your water wisely, prioritizing both your health
and the planet's well-being.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:46,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.h2,{children:"3. Container Material"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:52,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`When considering the material of the container for your water\u2014be it plastic or glass\u2014it's essential to
weigh the options. Glass is typically preferred over plastic, as it eliminates the concern of chemical
leaching into the water, which can occur with plastic containers. Often, water housed in glass tends
to be of superior quality and, consequently, a healthier choice.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:54,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`However, the cost factor is real; glass-bottled water can be a significant expense.
In such cases, a reliable water filter, once tested and verified, can serve as an economical and
effective substitute for bottled water.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:59,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.h2,{children:"4. Minerals & Additives"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:63,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`Many brands simply filter their water and reintroduce minerals artificially. These synthetic
minerals are typically of inferior quality when compared to those naturally present in water
and food sources.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:65,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`Moreover, it's not just about minerals. Certain water brands might also add subpar salt,
artificial flavors, or so-called "natural flavors," which could be detrimental to your health over time.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:69,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`So, what's the advisable course of action? Opt for water that contains naturally occurring
minerals, without any added extras\u2014this is the water humans have been drinking for millennia.
It's the most beneficial for your well-being. If that's not feasible, the next viable option is
filtering your water at home.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:72,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.h2,{children:"5. Additional contaminant concerns"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:77,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`Even with fluoride content managed and other factors addressed,
there could still be other contaminants lurking in bottled water.
Take Perrier as an instance \u2013 it may seem like a wise choice with
its low fluoride content (0.1 ppm), glass packaging, and natural spring
water origin. However, recent findings have indicated elevated levels of
PFAS in Perrier's sparkling water, which unfortunately disqualifies it.
Similarly, Topo Chico might appear appealing, but it was found to have
exceedingly high PFAS levels, raising concerns.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:79,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.h2,{children:"6. Water source"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:88,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`A significant issue with bottled water is the diversity of sources from which
brands procure their water. Consider Kirkland (Costco) - they market spring
water that looks uniform globally. Yet, a bottle purchased in Florida, USA
compared to one from LA, California will contain water from two distinct sources,
leading to potential differences in quality. One may have no detectable fluoride,
whereas the other could contain 0.3 ppm or more. Therefore, it's crucial to verify
the water's source with the information provided below.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:90,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`This is also why I have a preference for brands that exclusively source their water
from a single locale, ensuring consistency and peace of mind about the water's safety
and quality.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:98,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`The optimal approach for ensuring 100% confidence in water quality is
to use a water filtration system. The key advantage here is that you have full
control over the filtration process. With a high-quality water filter, the
chances of anything going awry are minimal.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:130,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`Alternatively, it is recommended to opt for bottled water from the brands
listed above, which offer natural water, packaged in glass, and with low
fluoride and other toxins. When it comes to other bottled water brands, the
risks outweigh the benefits. The presence of microplastics, unnatural minerals,
and additives, coupled with the uncertainty of the water's contents, makes them a
less desirable choice. Not to mention, the cost is often higher than justified.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:135,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.h2,{children:"More important information"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:142,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`It is imperative to examine not only the fluoride content but also the provenance
of the bottled water brand you choose. This refers to the original body of water
from which the company sources its product, whether it's a lake, river, or underground
aquifer. Understanding this ensures that even if two bottles appear identical,
they may contain vastly different water. Confirming the source is a definitive
step to guarantee that the water you're consuming has low fluoride levels.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:144,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:"Here are some strategies to assist you:"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:151,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.ol,{children:[`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.li,{children:`The source information is often listed on the bottle's label. Absence of this
detail typically implies the water has been filtered. Labels that indicate "Purified" or
"Distilled" suggest the water is devoid of fluoride.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:153,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.li,{children:`Look up the brand name for quicker access to information. On a computer, the shortcut

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.li,{children:`If you're not using the search function, the brands are organized alphabetically

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.li,{children:`The term \u201CFiltered\u201D on the label signifies the original water source is irrelevant

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`It's a common misconception that water filters strip away all the
beneficial minerals from water. Indeed, minerals are essential for our health,
but the truth is, tap water isn't a significant source of these nutrients.
The minerals that are present in tap water can be of questionable quality due
to potential damage from harsh treatment chemicals. When filtering tap water,
you're not missing out on much in terms of beneficial minerals.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:481,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`It's also worth noting that relying on water alone for your mineral intake isn't a
wise strategy. The quantities are simply too low, and if minerals are added to
water by a brand, they are often not of optimal quality. These synthetic additives
can be treated differently by the body compared to natural minerals.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:488,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`For an effective solution, incorporate these essential nutrients into your diet.
Alternatively, you can add a pinch of quality salt to your filtered water.
High-quality sea salt, or my personal preference, Redmond Real Salt, are excellent choices.
However, steer clear of regular white table salt, as it's typically stripped of its natural
benefits.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:493,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.strong,{children:"What about water brands not featured on this list?"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:499,columnNumber:1},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:499,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`If you come across a water brand that isn't featured on our recommended list,
don't worry. It can still be a viable option as long as it meets the following
criteria: it's natural, low in fluoride, free from additives, and ideally packaged
in glass. If you're uncertain about a brand, reach out with the name, and we can help
determine its suitability.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:501,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.strong,{children:"Is flavored water ok?"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:507,columnNumber:1},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:507,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`When it comes to flavored water, there's a sea of options that might not be as healthy
as they claim. Many brands use "natural flavors," a term that unfortunately often encompasses
a variety of undisclosed chemicals. The recommendation here is straightforward: choose brands
like Spindrift, which uses actual squeezed fruit in their beverages, ensuring an all-natural,
fluoride-free refreshment.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:509,columnNumber:1},this)]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx",lineNumber:1,columnNumber:1},this)}function Nn(b={}){let{wrapper:e}=b.components||{};return e?(0,n.jsxDEV)(e,Object.assign({},b,{children:(0,n.jsxDEV)(ve,b,void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx"},this)}),void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/water/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-2f485cd0-2d25-415b-a03c-af87ddb4134e.mdx"},this):ve(b)}var yn=Nn;return _n(wn);})();

title: Essentia Quality Test Report
description: Water quality report for Essentia water.

body.raw: Essentia treats their water through a process of: Purified water with minerals Processed by Filtration, Reverse Osmosis, Mineral Injection, Ionic Separation, Ozonation and UV, # Terms and Definitions - Statement of quality: the maximum legal limits for a substance in bottled water. The substances include pesticides, radiological contaminants, microbiological contaminants, organic chemicals, inorganic chemicals and others. The standards are established by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) - Maximum contaminant level (MCL): maximum level of a contaminant allowed in public drinking water - Primary drinking water standards (PDWS): maximum feasable protection of public health. Determined by the combination of ecomonimc and technological feasibility. - Public Health Goal (PHG): the level of a contaminant in drinking water below which there is no known or expected risk to health. PHGs are set by the California Environmental Protection Agency. # Ingredients - Purified Water (by Reverse Osmosis) - Sodium Bicarbonate - Dipotassium Phosphate - Magnesium Sulfate - Calcium Chloride (Electrolytes For Taste) ## Purified Water (by Reverse Osmosis) Reverse osmosis (RO) purified water represents a technological triumph in providing clean, safe drinking water. Here's the lowdown on how RO purified water can affect our health: Benefits of RO Purified Water: - Optimal Hydration: Reverse osmosis water is free from impurities and dissolved solids, making it an excellent choice for staying hydrated without the concern of consuming unwanted substances. - Taste Purity: The purification process strips away elements that might affect the taste, offering a clean and refreshing drinking experience. - Detoxified Option: With contaminants like lead, arsenic, and nitrates being removed, it serves as a safer alternative to tap water in areas where such pollutants are a concern. Potential Downsides to Consider: - Mineral Deficiency: Essential minerals found in water are also removed during reverse osmosis. This might necessitate an additional mineral intake from other dietary sources. - Acidity Levels: The lack of minerals can lead to a slightly more acidic pH level than is typical in natural water, which may affect sensitive individuals or those with specific health conditions. - Environmental Cost: The process is water-intensive, potentially wasting two to three gallons for every gallon purified, and the filters and membranes require periodic replacement, adding to environmental waste. In sum, reverse osmosis water is like a blank canvas—pristine and pure. It's an excellent medium for hydration, especially in areas where tap water quality is questionable, but just like a balanced diet, it's important to ensure you're getting your essential minerals from other sources. ## Sodium Bicarbonate Benefits: - pH Balance: Sodium Bicarbonate is alkaline, and its addition to drinking water can raise the pH level. This can be beneficial for those seeking to balance their body's pH or alleviate symptoms caused by high acidity, such as acid reflux. - Digestive Aid: In moderate amounts, Sodium Bicarbonate can help neutralize stomach acid, providing relief from indigestion and heartburn. It's a component of many over-the-counter antacids for this reason. - Electrolyte Balance: It provides a source of sodium, which is an essential electrolyte in the body. Proper electrolyte balance is crucial for hydration, muscle function, and nerve signaling. However, there are potential drawbacks to consider: - Sodium Intake: Increased consumption of Sodium Bicarbonate can lead to higher sodium intake, which might not be suitable for individuals with high blood pressure or those on a sodium-restricted diet. - Possible Overuse: Excessive use can lead to metabolic alkalosis, a condition where the body's pH becomes too alkaline, potentially causing symptoms like muscle weakness, twitching, or even seizures in severe cases. - Drug Interactions: It can interact with certain medications, altering their absorption or effectiveness. It's important to consult with a healthcare provider if on prescription drugs before increasing Sodium Bicarbonate intake. Sodium Bicarbonate in drinking water can offer some health benefits, particularly for digestive issues and maintaining a balanced internal pH. However, it's essential to use it judiciously to avoid the risks associated with high sodium consumption and potential health complications from overuse. As always, individual health conditions and dietary needs should be taken into account. Would you like to explore how to communicate these points to your audience, or is there another angle on this topic you're aiming to pursue? # Dipotassium Phosphate Dipotassium phosphate (DKP) emerges as a versatile compound, dissolving effortlessly into our water sources and playing multiple roles in our daily lives. Not only does it ensure our foods remain smooth and palatable, but it also nourishes our fields to yield bountiful harvests. Even our taps may carry traces of DKP, a testament to its widespread utility. Key Insights into Dipotassium Phosphate's Presence in Water: - Nutrient Powerhouse: DKP doubles as a nutritional dynamo, offering a bounty of phosphorus and potassium – minerals pivotal for robust bones, high-octane energy levels, and the smooth functioning of our hearts and muscles. - Guardian of Balance: Echoing the role of sodium bicarbonate, DKP stands guard as a pH stabilizer, safeguarding our water systems from corrosive threats and ensuring a harmonious aquatic balance. - Stamp of Approval: The watchful eyes of the FDA have deemed DKP safe for consumption, provided it's woven into manufacturing processes with care and precision. Yet, we must navigate the flip side with equal vigilance: - The Perils of Excess: Overindulgence in DKP can spell trouble, especially for individuals navigating the delicate waters of kidney health, where monitoring phosphate intake is not just wise but necessary. - Calcium's Nemesis: In the delicate dance of minerals within our bodies, an overabundance of phosphorus could tip the scales against calcium, leaving our bones at a potential disadvantage. - A Question of the Heart: Emerging studies whisper concerns about phosphates and heart health, but the conversation is ongoing, awaiting clearer answers. Embracing the dual-edged nature of dipotassium phosphate in our drinking water, we recognize its beneficial embrace and its potential sting. Each individual's health mosaic and DKP's concentration in their water become the critical lenses through which we must examine its role in our lives. As we navigate these waters, moderation remains our trusty compass, and the counsel of health experts, our guiding stars. # Magnesium Sulfate In the intricate dance of minerals and compounds that grace our drinking water, Magnesium Sulfate – often referred to as Epsom salt when in its heptahydrate form – plays a nuanced role. This compound, more than just a simple ingredient, can influence our well-being, depending on its presence in our water supply. Let's unfold the narrative of Magnesium Sulfate and its double-edged sword upon human health. The Tale of Magnesium Sulfate in Drinking Water: - A Mineral Maestro: Magnesium Sulfate is a source of magnesium, a mineral maestro in the symphony of our bodily functions. It aids in over 300 enzymatic reactions, fortifying bones, and supporting nerve and muscle function. - A Relaxation Respite: When present in water, it can be a relaxation agent, soothing muscles and providing a calming effect, akin to the tranquility one finds in a warm, Epsom salt bath. - A Digestive Gentleman: In moderate amounts, it can serve as a gentle laxative, easing the tribulations of a troubled digestive tract and fostering regularity with the grace of a butler's discreet assistance. However, striking a balance is key, as the tale of Magnesium Sulfate is not without its shadows: - An Unwelcomed Excess: An excess intake of Magnesium Sulfate, particularly for those with renal complications, can be problematic, leading to an overture of unwanted health effects such as diarrhea or more severe issues like magnesium toxicity. - A Kidney's Burden: The kidneys bear the onus of filtering out excess magnesium; too grand a task can stress these vital organs, particularly in individuals with kidney disease. - An Electrolyte Imbalance: Immoderate consumption can lead to an imbalance of electrolytes in the body, disrupting the harmonious rhythm of our internal processes. In essence, like the delicate balance of a well-orchestrated ensemble, Magnesium Sulfate in our drinking water must be fine-tuned to our individual health compositions and needs. While it can sing a soothing melody of benefits, it's critical to listen to the underlying notes and ensure they harmonize with our body’s unique requirements. ## Calcium Chloride Calcium chloride, a compound you might recognize from its role in road deicing or as a firming agent in canned vegetables, is also a player in the water we drink. But like any character in the drama of our dietary intake, it wears both white and black hats depending on the scene. Let's set the stage for how this compound interacts with our body's intricate workings when it's a part of our drinking water. - The Bone Benefactor: In the grand theater of human health, calcium is the lead actor for strong bones and teeth. When calcium chloride is present in water, it contributes to the daily calcium performance, ensuring that the skeletal framework remains robust and resilient against the test of time. - Muscle Maestro: Like a conductor's baton guiding the orchestra, calcium is essential for the proper function of muscles. It helps in the contraction and relaxation phases, ensuring that each muscle note is hit with precision. - Electrolyte Ensemble: In the human body's fluid symphony, electrolytes like calcium play a crucial role in maintaining the harmony of hydration. Calcium chloride in water can be a source of these electrolytes, tuning the body's fluid balance to a perfect pitch. - Heart's Rhythm Section: Calcium's role in heart health cannot be understated—it's the rhythm section that keeps the beat steady and strong. Adequate calcium intake from all sources, including water, supports the heart in its tireless rhythm. However, even the most beneficial elements can hit a sour note if the composition isn't balanced: - The Salty Solo: Calcium chloride is saltier to the taste than its counterpart, calcium sulfate. This can be a discordant note for taste buds expecting the neutral taste of pure water, leading to a less than refreshing experience. - Desiccation Dynamics: Calcium chloride has a hygroscopic nature, meaning it can attract and hold water molecules from its surroundings. In excess, this could potentially lead to a drying effect on the body, requiring one to be mindful of the balance of intake. - The Kidney's Critique: While the kidneys are adept at maintaining mineral balance, an overabundance of calcium—especially in the presence of an underlying renal condition—can overtax these vital organs, causing a cacophony of health issues. - Scale Accumulation: In the pipes and purviews of our water systems, calcium chloride can contribute to scale buildup. While not a direct health concern, it's a logistical aria that can affect water quality and appliance longevity. As we navigate the waters of our daily consumption, it's essential to consider the sources and amounts of calcium chloride we're inviting in. While it can be a supporting actor contributing to the overall performance of our health, we must ensure it doesn't steal the show with potential overexposure. It's all about maintaining a harmonious balance in the liquid libretto of life. # Test Results - '\*' indicates th maximum levels have been exceeded - ND indicates that the substance was not detected title: Smartwater Quality Test Report
description: Breaking down what's inside Smartwater and how it affects your health, with a water quality test report.

body.raw: # Ingredients in Smartwater - Calcium Chloride: - Magnesium Chloride - Potassium Bicarbonate - Electrolytes ## Effects of Calcium Chloride Taking calcium chloride on board through your water supply can be a bit of a double-edged sword. It's widely accepted as a safe additive by the FDA, falling under the GRAS category, but there's a twist—it's all about moderation. Here's the scoop—adding a sprinkle of calcium chloride to your H2O can actually be a boon for your bones and vital bodily functions thanks to its calcium payload. But crank up the dose, and you might be biting off more than you can chew, health-wise. Let's dive into the nitty-gritty: 1. **Stomach Upset**: Chugging too much calcium chloride can ruffle your digestive feathers, causing anything from an upset stomach to more serious issues like ulcers if you really overdo it. 2. **Electrolyte Tango**: Calcium's a bigwig in the electrolyte world, keeping things in check. But an overload from calcium chloride can throw your body's delicate dance of electrolytes out of whack, possibly leading to a surplus of calcium in the bloodstream, known as hypercalcemia. This unwanted guest can bring along fatigue, confusion, and even heart and kidney drama. 3. **Moisture Magnet**: High amounts of calcium chloride can act like a sponge, pulling moisture right out of your cells and potentially leading to dehydration. 4. **Salty Sip**: Too much calcium chloride can give your water a salty edge, which might not sit well with your taste buds, leading you to drink less water overall—not exactly the goal. 5. **Medication Mishaps**: This compound doesn't play nice with certain meds, potentially messing with how your body absorbs them—think antibiotics or bone-strengthening drugs. Now, it's paramount that the calcium chloride levels in your water stay within the safe embrace of health authority guidelines. Got a particular level or scenario on your mind? A chat with a health expert or a peek at the official guidelines will give you the lowdown for your specific situation. ## Effects of Magnesium Chloride In the realm of hydration, a dash of magnesium chloride in your water does more than quench your thirst—it's a wellness powerhouse. This mineral champion plays a pivotal role in keeping your body's symphony in tune, from fortifying your bones to orchestrating the rhythm of your heart and muscles. Let's dive into the transformative impact of magnesium chloride in your daily sips: Daily Dose of Wellness: Sipping water that's kissed with the right amount of magnesium chloride serves up a slice of the essential nutrients your body craves. It's like a silent guardian against the specter of magnesium scarcity, shielding you from the specters of muscle spasms, weariness, and even off-beat heart tempos. Digestive Harmony: Magnesium chloride is the more forgiving cousin of calcium chloride, offering a gentle touch to your gut in modest portions. But don't be fooled—overindulgence can still usher in a bout of digestive rebellion and laxative-like effects. Heartfelt Benefits: Your heart will thank you for a steady supply of magnesium, which plays a key role in keeping your blood pressure in check and your heart beating to the right drumbeat, potentially keeping hypertension and cardiac concerns at bay. A Whisper of Flavor: Unlike its counterpart, magnesium chloride is the understated note in your water's flavor profile, ensuring your taste buds remain blissfully unaware of its presence. A Delicate Dance with Medications: Just as with calcium chloride, magnesium chloride demands a careful two-step when it comes to certain medications and health conditions. It's not the best dance partner for everyone, particularly for those navigating kidney challenges or the high seas of hypermagnesemia. To ensure the harmonious balance of magnesium in your body, sticking to the melody of recommended guidelines is key. Overstepping these bounds can introduce a cacophony of health complications, especially for those whose kidneys don't play the encore efficiently. ## Effects of Potassium Bicarbonate **Benefits:** - Electrolyte Balance: Potassium is a vital electrolyte, helping to maintain the body's acid-base balance. - Blood Pressure Control: Potassium can aid in lowering high blood pressure by counteracting the effects of sodium. - Muscular Function: This mineral is important for normal muscular function, including the heart muscle. **Harms (when consumed in excessive amounts):** - Gastrointestinal Issues: May cause stomach discomfort, nausea, or vomiting. - Electrolyte Imbalance: Too much potassium can lead to hyperkalemia, impacting heart rhythm and muscle function. - Kidney Stress: High potassium intake can strain kidneys, especially in individuals with pre-existing kidney conditions. It's crucial to consume it in moderation, and it's always wise to consult with a healthcare professional before making changes to your diet or water intake. How does this information align with your current needs? Would you like to delve deeper into a specific aspect of this topic? ## Effects of Electrolytes Diving into the world of electrolytes, it's like stepping into the matrix of our body's functionality—each one playing a crucial role in the symphony of our well-being. Let's hit some high notes and low notes on what happens when these charged characters waltz into our system through drinking water: **Positive Vibrations: The Upside of Electrolytes** - Hydration Maestro: Electrolytes are the conductors of the hydration orchestra, ensuring that fluids are harmoniously distributed throughout the body for optimal performance. - Nerve and Muscle Ensemble: They're the unsung heroes in the nerve impulse and muscle contraction band, essential for those epic body movements and groovy dance moves. - pH Balance Jam: The perfect pH is like hitting the right tune, and electrolytes keep the body rocking at the perfect acid-base harmony. - Endurance Tune-up: Sipping on that electrolyte-infused water can be like a turbo boost for endurance levels, keeping you going like the Energizer Bunny. **A Sour Note: The Potential Downsides** - Overhydration Overdrive: Too much of a good thing can lead to a water-electrolyte imbalance, potentially causing a condition known as hyponatremia—think of it as drowning from the inside. - High Voltage Issues: Excessively rocking out on certain electrolytes might lead to hypertension, like a guitar amped up too high, putting a strain on the heart. - Kidney's Cry for Encore: The kidneys are like the roadies of our body, cleaning up after the show, but too many electrolytes can leave them overwhelmed and begging for a break. Remember, moderation is key—like a well-mixed track, the right balance of electrolytes can keep the body's concert going strong. So, keep it groovy, and let your healthcare professional be the VIP backstage pass to your health decisions. How about we dive into another topic that's got you curious? # Test Results A 2018 sample water quality analysis for smartwater is listed below. Please note that in the results column of each table “ND” indicates Non-Detected. ## Residual Disinfectants | Standard of Quality (mg/L) | Results (mg/L) | | -------------------------- | -------------- | | Chloramine (4) | ND | | Chlorine (4) | ND | | Chlorine Dioxide (0.8) | ND | ## Radionuclides | Standard of Quality (pCi/L) | Results (pCi/L) | | ---------------------------------- | --------------- | | Gross Alpha particle activity (15) | ND | | Gross Beta particle (50) | ND | | Radium 226 (3) | ND | | Radium 228 (5) | ND | | Uranium (0.03 mg/L) | ND | ## Microbiological | Standard of Quality | Results | | ------------------------ | ----------------------------------- | | Coliform (< 4 CFU/100mL) | Absent (Membrane Filtration Method) | ## Physical Quality | Standard of Quality | Results | | ------------------- | ------- | | Color (15 Units) | Pass | | Odor (3) | Pass | | Turbidity (5 Units) | Pass | ## Organic Components | Standard of Quality (mg/L) | Results (mg/L) | | ---------------------------- | -------------- | | Aluminum (0.2) | ND | | Antimony (0.006) | ND | | Arsenic (0.01) | ND | | Barium (2) | ND | | Beryllium (0.004) | ND | | Cadmium (0.005) | ND | | Chloride (250) | Pass | | Chromium (0.1) | ND | | Copper (1) | ND | | Cyanide (0.2) | ND | | Fluoride (1.4 – 2.4) | ND | | Iron (0.3) | ND | | Lead (0.005) | ND | | Manganese (0.05) | ND | | Mercury (0.002) | ND | | Nitrate (as N) (10) | Pass | | Nitrite (as N) (1) | ND | | Phenols (0.001) | ND | | Selenium (0.05) | ND | | Silver (0.1) | ND | | Sulfate (250) | ND | | Thallium (0.002) | ND | | Total Dissolved Solids (500) | Pass | ## Sources https://article.images.consumerreports.org/image/upload/prod/pdf/cq_water_reports/SmartWater_2018.pdf
